description: uv, ruff, pyproject.toml, modern toolchain, Python 3.11-3.14 highlights

cards.front: What is uv and what does it replace?
cards.back:
uv is a fast Python package manager written in Rust.
It replaces:
- pip (package install)
- python -m venv (virtual environments)
- pyenv (Python version management)
- pip-tools (lock files)

uv venv          # create environment
uv pip install X  # install packages

10-100x faster than pip.

cards.front: What is ruff and what does it replace?
cards.back:
ruff is a fast linter and formatter written in Rust.
It replaces:
- flake8 (linting) -> ruff check
- black (formatting) -> ruff format
- isort (import sorting) -> ruff check --select I

ruff check .        # find problems
ruff check . --fix  # auto-fix
ruff format .       # format code

The modern Python config file. Replaces setup.py, setup.cfg, and scattered config files.

[project]
name = "my-project"
version = "0.1.0"
dependencies = ["requests>=2.31"]

[tool.ruff]
line-length = 88

[tool.pytest.ini_options]
testpaths = ["tests"]

One file, all configuration.

cards.front: What improved in Python 3.11 error messages?
cards.back:
Python 3.11 points to the EXACT expression that caused the error.

result = data["users"][0]["email"]
                          ^^^^^^^
KeyError: 'email'

Before 3.11: only the line number. Now Python underlines the exact problematic part.

cards.front: What does f"{x=}" do in an f-string?
cards.back:
Prints both the variable name and its value. Great for debugging.

x = 42
name = "Alice"
items = [1, 2, 3]

print(f"{x=}")            # x=42
print(f"{name=}")         # name='Alice'
print(f"{len(items)=}")   # len(items)=3

Available since Python 3.8.

cards.front: What is the old-to-new Python toolchain mapping?
cards.back:
pip -> uv pip
python -m venv -> uv venv
pyenv -> uv python
pip-tools -> uv lock
flake8 -> ruff check
black -> ruff format
isort -> ruff check --select I
setup.py -> pyproject.toml

You do not need to adopt everything at once. Start with uv + ruff.

cards.front: What is tomllib and when was it added?
cards.back:
A built-in TOML parser added in Python 3.11.

import tomllib

with open("pyproject.toml", "rb") as f:
    config = tomllib.load(f)

print(config["project"]["name"])

No third-party library needed. Note: read in binary mode ("rb").

cards.front: What common mistake happens when mixing pip and uv?
cards.back:
Both write to the same .venv/, which causes confusion about what is installed.

Pick one and stick with it for each project.

Also: always check for (.venv) in your terminal prompt.
If it is missing, you are using system Python, not your virtual environment.
